{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3343473,"name":"Myer","username":"myer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/myer/{size}/217120_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T00:19:31.668Z","cooked":"

Normally, I would troubleshoot the problem more myself, but since we are nearing in on a competition, I thought that any input would be great.

The problem we are facing right now is that communications are being lost during a specific action sequence. After we intake a note, spool up the shooter, and feed the note into the shooter, communications are lost. Communications are lost only after the note is fired and has made it into the goal; as in, spooling up the shooter for a longer period of time and then feeding in the note will delay the communications drop. Also, doing the same sequence of actions without a note inside (running the intake, spooling up the shooter, then running the motor that would feed the note) will not cause a communications drop. Only if a note is inside the robot will communications be dropped. This is the part that baffles me the most, but it could be that the note causes more power to be drawn from the shooter since it needs to spit the note out.

After communications are lost, they are restored almost immediately (~3 seconds), but we must re-enable teleop. It does appear that the code restarts (the communications bar turns red and the robot code bar also turns red), but again I cannot find code issues. Our code is here (the relevant files are probably Constants.java and any file with Shooter in the title).

Any help would be appreciated and I will continue trying to solve the problem tomorrow. This issue has cropped up today only and has not occurred before.

Maybe, just maybe static? I would check other things first for sure (can you make sure you aren’t getting a brown-out on the Rio?

We think we might be suffering from static on our shooter from notes building it up as they slide through. Not the easiest thing to verify is the root cause though.

It sounds like static may be your problem. From the length of the disconnection, I would suspect the Ethernet switch. Is that located anywhere near the shooter?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":40,"updated_at":"2024-03-26T00:45:14.737Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":397,"readers_count":396,"score":84.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":460115,"topic_slug":"loss-of-communications-during-certain-actions","display_username":"Gavin Matthews","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":55295,"username":"ca2devri","name":"4907 mentor & enthusiast","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ca2devri/{size}/189324_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38743,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming mentor, Team 2102, RI, CSA (he/him)"},"post_url":"/t/loss-of-communications-during-certain-actions/460115/3","custom_user_title":"Programming mentor, Team 2102, RI, CSA (he/him)","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3343500,"name":"Max Morehead","username":"Max_Morehead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/max_morehead/{size}/231937_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T00:50:07.491Z","cooked":"

How do you verify that static is an issue? We experienced some odd issues with a Spark MAX mounted near some wheels this year, but I don’t have any understanding of what the effects of static are on an electrical system.

Are there any rules of thumbs about avoiding static discharge, and can static discharge permanently damage robot electronics? And how would OP fix the issue if it is static? Move the location of the ethernet switch?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":40,"updated_at":"2024-03-26T00:50:50.575Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":373,"readers_count":372,"score":94.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":460115,"topic_slug":"loss-of-communications-during-certain-actions","display_username":"Max Morehead","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53784,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/loss-of-communications-during-certain-actions/460115/4","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3343501,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T00:50:40.696Z","cooked":"

Some long-shots (no pun intended) that you may or may not have already done:
remove the D from PIDF.
Add current limits to all the suspected motors after you tune the PIDF.
Make the PID uni-directional in some way. That is make sure it isn’t sending a reverse motor command to get back from any overshoot of the setpoint. Use a clamp or voltage compensation command to do that. Also, tune the PID to make sure it overshoots the setpoint very little.
Move the radio away from the motor/motor controller.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":40,"updated_at":"2024-03-26T00:56:44.538Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":289,"readers_count":288,"score":57.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":460115,"topic_slug":"loss-of-communications-during-certain-actions","display_username":"Myer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64553,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1350 | Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/loss-of-communications-during-certain-actions/460115/6","custom_user_title":"1350 | Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3343510,"name":"Gavin Matthews","username":"bovlb","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bovlb/{size}/167232_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T00:57:17.804Z","cooked":"

Here are two ways you could test that static is the issue:

  • Watch the lights on the device during the problem
  • Attach a grounding strap to the shooter during the test.

My advice would be to move electronics further away and consider shielding. I have heard of teams trying to ground their robot with a piece of tinsel that drags on the ground, but I don’t know either if that would work, or if it would get past inspection.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":40,"updated_at":"2024-03-26T00:57:17.804Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":271,"readers_count":270,"score":84.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":460115,"topic_slug":"loss-of-communications-during-certain-actions","display_username":"Gavin Matthews","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":53784,"username":"Max_Morehead","name":"Max Morehead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/max_morehead/{size}/231937_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38743,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming mentor, Team 2102, RI, CSA (he/him)"},"post_url":"/t/loss-of-communications-during-certain-actions/460115/7","custom_user_title":"Programming mentor, Team 2102, RI, CSA (he/him)","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3343514,"name":"Myer","username":"myer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/myer/{size}/217120_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T00:58:07.855Z","cooked":"
bovlb:

It sounds like static may be your problem. From the length of the disconnection, I would suspect the Ethernet switch. Is that located anywhere near the shooter?

The note basically passes over the ethernet switch while it is slid into place and the switch is mounted on a metal bar, so this could definitely be the reason. Will look into it tomorrow.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":40,"updated_at":"2024-03-26T01:12:58.158Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":258,"readers_count":257,"score":71.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":460115,"topic_slug":"loss-of-communications-during-certain-actions","display_username":"Myer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64553,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1350 | Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/loss-of-communications-during-certain-actions/460115/8","custom_user_title":"1350 | Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3343519,"name":"Myer","username":"myer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/myer/{size}/217120_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T01:00:00.918Z","cooked":"
bovlb:

Here are two ways you could test that static is the issue:

  • Watch the lights on the device during the problem
  • Attach a grounding strap to the shooter during the test.

My advice would be to move electronics further away and consider shielding. I have heard of teams trying to ground their robot with a piece of tinsel that drags on the ground, but I don’t know either if that would work, or if it would get past inspection.

Will try this tomorrow.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":40,"updated_at":"2024-03-26T01:12:42.641Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":239,"readers_count":238,"score":47.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":460115,"topic_slug":"loss-of-communications-during-certain-actions","display_username":"Myer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64553,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1350 | Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/loss-of-communications-during-certain-actions/460115/9","custom_user_title":"1350 | Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3343534,"name":"Myer","username":"myer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/myer/{size}/217120_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T01:12:22.019Z","cooked":"
SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

Add current limits to all the suspected motors after you tune the PIDF.

I’m using NEO Brushless, so there is supposed to be a built in current limit.

SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

Make the PID uni-directional in some way. That is make sure it isn’t sending a reverse motor command to get back from any overshoot of the setpoint.

Not sure how I would do this but I don’t even use a PID control on the shooter, just a feed forward since we are usually always just running the shooter to max RPM.

SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

Move the radio away from the motor/motor controller.

Definitely going to do this tomorrow as it seems like many people have had similar experiences.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":40,"updated_at":"2024-03-26T01:12:22.019Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":229,"readers_count":228,"score":60.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":460115,"topic_slug":"loss-of-communications-during-certain-actions","display_username":"Myer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64553,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1350 | Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/loss-of-communications-during-certain-actions/460115/10","custom_user_title":"1350 | Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3343545,"name":"","username":"flametek","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/flametek/{size}/235833_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T01:19:37.166Z","cooked":"

We used 6 AWG copper wire to ground us to the carpet and it passed inspection. It was also a great talking point for judges

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":40,"updated_at":"2024-03-26T01:19:37.166Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":214,"readers_count":213,"score":57.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":460115,"topic_slug":"loss-of-communications-during-certain-actions","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":38743,"username":"bovlb","name":"Gavin Matthews","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bovlb/{size}/167232_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58068,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"rapid react's #1 fan"},"post_url":"/t/loss-of-communications-during-certain-actions/460115/11","custom_user_title":"rapid react's #1 fan","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3343567,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-26T01:30:54.327Z","cooked":"
myer:

I’m using NEO Brushless, so there is supposed to be a built in current limit.

Yes - sort of - it’s actually the SparkMax, and it is higher than what Rev recommends.

Out of the box, the SPARK MAX’s Smart Current Limit default setting is 80A for any motor that you use. We recommend utilizing our locked-rotor testing data or the table below to decide what to set your Smart Current Limit to for your robot: Locked-Rotor Testing for the NEO (REV-21-1650) and NEO 550 (REV-21-1651).

Remember that some settings, like Smart Current Limit, must be burned to flash via code or the Hardware Client in order to be retained through a power cycle of the SPARK MAX.

Suggested Current Limits

Your ideal current limit may vary based on your specific application, but these values can be used as a starting point to reduce the chance of an overload on your motor as you begin tuning your specific mechanism’s Smart Current Limit.

Motor Type Current Limit Range
NEO (REV-21-1650) 40A - 60A
NEO 550 (REV-21-1651) 20A - 40A

Locked-rotor Testing","clicks":2},{"url":"https://www.revrobotics.com/neo-550-brushless-motor-locked-rotor-testing/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"NEO 550 Brushless Motor - Locked-rotor Testing","clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.revrobotics.com/rev-21-1650/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"NEO Brushless Motor V1.1 - We had this exact same issue; are you using a Brainboxes switch? We switched to a TP-Link switch with a VRM and that resolved the problem. Others have found that connecting a Brainboxes switch to an external regulator resolves this. Grounding straps helped, but we were still able to reproduce the issue very occasionally. For us, it was due to static from notes shooting through our robot. Check the orange light on the RIO ethernet port to see if it turns off when you shoot, that’s a good indication that your switch is rebooting.

superpenguin612:

We had this exact same issue; are you using a Brainboxes switch?

We weren’t able to get our hands on a Brainboxes switch since we ordered this last minute (I guess I didn’t do enough research on what was required to wire our Limelight). This is the switch we got, and it is wired directly into the REV PDH.

superpenguin612:

Check the orange light on the RIO ethernet port to see if it turns off when you shoot, that’s a good indication that your switch is rebooting.

I will try shooting again tomorrow and look at the RIO ethernet light. Thanks for the feedback.

Try putting the switch on a buck/boost converter to ensure it is always getting 12v as well. The spike in electrical load from shooting the note may be taking battery voltage low enough to cause issues with the switch.

Yep, this is your issue. Your switch does not have a built in regulator, it is designed to take in clean 12V.

image512×736 57 KB

Connecting straight to Vbat on a switch like this will cause it to reboot under high current draw events. I would connect this to a VRM’s 12v2a ports, and that should fix your issue.

Will talk to electrical about this and update later today when we’re in the lab. Thanks for the suggestion.

superpenguin612:

I would connect this to a VRM’s 12v2a ports

Only if that VRM isn’t also powering the radio. If it is, then the radio has to be the only load on the 12V/2A ports. You can always add a second VRM, move the radio to an RPM, or use any COTS voltage regulator rated for 5-14V input.
